At least a quarter of the Earth's warming is due to anthropogenic methane emissions. Multiple satellites in orbit and planned for launch in the next few years can detect and quantify these emissions, but to attribute methane emissions to their sources on the ground, a comprehensive database of the locations and characteristics of emission sources worldwide is essential. This work develops deep learning algorithms that leverage freely available high-resolution aerial imagery to automatically detect oil and gas infrastructure, a major contributor to global methane emissions. The best algorithm, called OGNet, is used together with expert review to identify the locations of oil refineries and petroleum terminals in the U.S. OGNet detects many facilities not present in four standard public datasets of oil and gas infrastructure. All detected facilities are associated with characteristics known to contribute to methane emissions, including infrastructure type and the number of storage tanks. The data curated and produced in this study is freely available at http://stanfordmlgroup.github.io/projects/ognet.

Methane is the second-largest contributor to climate warming after carbon dioxide and accounts for at least one-quarter of present-day warming. Around a third of current global anthropogenic methane emissions arise from the fossil fuel sector, and reducing these emissions is critical to mitigate further warming in the near-term. In the last decade, quantifying methane emissions from the oil and gas sector has become a significant area of research and interest to both governments and the oil and gas industry. Recent progress in quantifying methane emissions from the oil and gas sector has been largely due to advancements in satellite-based observations. Multiple global mapping satellite missions provide atmospheric methane concentrations data, and limited coverage satellites can detect high emission rates from specific facilities. A new satellite, MethaneSAT, planned for launch in 2022, will provide publicly available methane emissions data to help drive action towards reducing emissions and for companies and countries to track their emission reduction targets.

To attribute methane emissions detected by these satellites to facilities on the ground, a comprehensive database of the locations and characteristics of oil and gas infrastructure worldwide is critically required. Prior efforts to construct public datasets of oil and gas facilities have been made, including the global oil and gas infrastructure database (GOGI) and national programs such as the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) and the U.S. Energy Mapping System. However, these datasets have limitations, including data gaps and incomplete coverage. The recent availability of high-resolution satellite and aerial imagery, together with advancements in deep learning methods, offer a powerful opportunity to create high-quality, granular, and large-scale databases of global infrastructure. Deep learning techniques have been increasingly utilized for automatically detecting objects in remotely sensed imagery, including building footprint detection and urban land use classification. In this work, we develop deep learning models to automatically detect oil and gas infrastructure in freely available aerial imagery. We deploy the best models in the full continental U.S. to map oil refineries and petroleum terminals and attribute each facility with characteristics known to contribute to methane emissions.
